queue.fact_text: In 1962, Wilt Chamberlain scored an astonishing 100 points in a single NBA game, a record that still feels almost mythical. Played in a small Pennsylvania arena and barely televised, the game lives on through stat sheets, grainy photos, and the legend of an impossible night.

queue.fact_text: In 1867, the U.S. Congress passed the first Reconstruction Act, placing former Confederate states under military rule and outlining conditions for their readmission. episode.title: Morning Drops #43 - Looking Back

It touches on the vulnerability of the body, the unexpected joy found in daily progress, and the warmth that comes from finally allowing oneself to accept help. The musical selection mirrors this path of recovery, moving from the uncertainty of change to the steady rhythm of healing.

queue.fact_text: In 1859, the "Great Slave Auction" began in Georgia, where 436 enslaved people were sold over two days—the largest such auction recorded in U.S. history. episode.title: Morning Drops #42 - The Joy Of Learning
episode.description:
Hosted by Yasmin, this Morning Drop explores learning as a lifelong process, focusing on persistence, repetition, and the emotional landscape that comes with challenging oneself over time.

Through personal stories and scientific insights, the episode looks at how learning reshapes the brain, generates joy through effort, and why progress often arrives after confusion and frustration. It reflects on the so-called delayed pleasure effect, the role of dopamine in motivation, and how curiosity and learning support long-term wellbeing.

The episode also questions our cultural relationship with failure and invites a softer, more realistic approach to learning, one that accepts mistakes as part of growth and sees persistence as a quiet form of strength.

Mood: reflective, grounded, quietly hopeful
Music genre: alternative rock, hip hop, electronic, neo-soul, drill

A space to listen slowly and stay with the process.
